title: Xi Jinping Flexes China's Trade Muscle With Visit to Rare-Earths Hub
summary: Tour touts country's position as top provider of elements needed for high-tech endeavors. title: JPMorgan Shareholders Approve Jamie Dimon's Pay
summary: Shareholder-advisory firm criticized bank for lack of clarity on how compensation is determined. JPMorgan Chase & Co. investors voted to approve Chief Executive James Dimon's pay at the bank's annual meeting over the objections of a shareholder-advisory firm.

title: Storm System Sets Off Dozens of Tornadoes
summary: Flooding leads to some rescues, as officials express relief that the worst didn't happen. An unusually dangerous storm system produced dozens of tornadoes that were either seen or spotted on radar across the Texas Panhandle and Oklahoma, but officials reported relatively limited damage.

title: Investigation Pokes Holes in 1976 Murder Conviction
summary: Suffolk County, N.Y., district attorney's office will disclose findings that could lead to historic overturning of conviction. Keith Bush was convicted of the murder and attempted rape of a teenage girl in Bellport, N.Y., that occurred when he was 17 years old. He served 33 years in prison and remains under state supervision as a lifetime parolee and a level-three sex offender.

title: An Immigrant's Gift to America
summary: The Statue of Liberty gets a stunning new museum.. America's been good to Diane von Furstenberg, who built her fashion empire after arriving on these shores as a 22-year-old, pregnant immigrant from Belgium. Now Ms. von Furstenberg has shown her gratitude by leading a successful effort to raise $100 million for a new Statue of Liberty Museum that opened last week.

title: Don McGahn's Immunity
summary: Why Congress can't force the former White House counsel to testify.. Democrats are fuming that Don McGahn skipped a Congressional hearing on Tuesday, and they plan to hold the former White House counsel in contempt. But Mr. McGahn has every constitutional right not to appear, and this isn't a close legal call.

title: Austrian Chancellor Faces No-Confidence Vote
summary: Call for vote comes days after conservative leader's coalition with scandal-racked nationalists dissolved. The unraveling of an alliance between conservatives and nationalists in Austria's government is now threatening to end the 18-month tenure of Chancellor Sebastian Kurz, as opposition parties demanded a vote of no confidence in his leadership.

title: Trump to Visit Ireland, Meet Prime Minister
summary: President's first visit to the country since he was elected set for June 5. WASHINGTON-President Trump will make his first trip to Ireland since winning the White House when he meets Prime Minister Leo Varadkar next month in Shannon, an Irish town about an hour away from the president's golf course in Doonbeg.

title: Britain's Conservative Collapse
summary: Voters seem ready to crush the Tories for their bungling over Brexit.. British voters head to the polls Thursday for a European Parliament election they weren't supposed to vote in, and the biggest loser is likely to be the ruling Conservative Party. Ignoring Brexit for a moment-yes, it's possible-the most consequential development in Europe the last two years is the collapse of the Tories as a governing party.

title: The Face-Recognition Panic
summary: We don't need bans. The give-and-take of democracy will protect us from abuse.. In the near future, it's conceivable you will be able to show your phone a picture of a human face and a commercial service will tell you where that face has shown up recently on networked public cameras. You will also get a little information about that person based on social-media postings and other public information on the internet.

title: An Opening for Immigration Reform
summary: Sen. Lindsey Graham leads, but he'll need help from Democrats and President Trump.. Taking a break from his campaign to ward off a primary challenge from his right, Republican Sen. Lindsey Graham opened the door last week to a bipartisan immigration compromise. While unveiling a tough proposal to address the surge of migrants from Central America, the South Carolinian invited Democrats to work their own priorities into the legislation. He cited Illinois Sen. Dick Durbin's long advocacy of a bill to give legal status to the "Dreamers"-young adults brought to the U.S. illegally as children.

title: 'Spying on the South' Review: The Forever Cotton Kingdom
summary: Traveling the American South, the author paints an image of a region still wrestling with the aftereffects of slavery and the Civil War.. A decade or so before the Civil War, an aimless young man accepted an assignment from the newly established New York Times. His task: to travel through the exotic hinterlands of the South and report on what he encountered. Frederick Law Olmsted, 30 years old and destined to become the nation's foremost landscape architect, had already tried his hand at a number of unrewarding occupations: apprentice seaman, merchant, author and farmer. With no definite itinerary and no idea what he might find, he wandered through Virginia, the Deep South, Texas and the borderlands separating the U.S. from Mexico. In the process, he wrote what remains one of the most perceptive accounts of the slaveholding South in our national literature, a collection of columns eventually published as "The Cotton Kingdom."

title: No Wall Can Fill Holes in the Law
summary: Physical barriers divert the flow of migrants across the border. Stanching it will take new asylum policies.. A pale yellow gate stands 4 feet high on a bridge over a rural Arizona irrigation ditch. The nondescript structure epitomizes the challenges of securing the southern border.

title: Sanders Chooses Teachers Unions Over Black Voters
summary: The candidate calls for a moratorium on charter schools. It's bad politics and even worse policy.. Black voters had little use for Bernie Sanders when he sought the presidency in 2016. In the South Carolina primary, exit polls showed him winning only 14% of the black vote, while 86% went to Hillary Clinton. The Vermont socialist knows he must up his game with this constituency to have any chance of winning the 2020 Democratic nomination, but his recent attack on school choice may wind up costing him minority support.

title: China Risks Hong Kong's Economic Freedom
summary: An extradition bill would weaken the territory's already shaky rule of law.. Hong Kong has stood alone for 25 years atop the Heritage Foundation's annual Index of Economic Freedom. The index scores 180 economies around the world in 12 categories of economic freedom related to the rule of law, regulatory efficiency, government size and the openness of markets. It averages those scores to get an overall economic freedom score on a 100-point scale. Hong Kong's lead over perennial second-place finisher Singapore has been as wide as 4 points, but in recent years Hong Kong's lead has dwindled to less than a point.

title: A Plagiarist Walks Into a Comedy Club
summary: Louis C.K. warns audiences not to steal his jokes, while Conan O'Brien settles a lawsuit.. Well, this is a hoot. The same week that one top comedian threatened his audience with legal action if jokes were filched from his act, another settled a lawsuit about joke-stealing by noting that "different people around the world come up with the same joke all the time." Comedy professionals rarely consider stealing material a laughing matter, but it doesn't usually lead to litigation.

The 40-year-old Los Angeles interior designer, known for her extravagantly bohemian "Jungalow" aesthetic, has staked her career on the power of design and an inspiring lifestyle. So when, three years ago, she found herself poised to appear on the cover of a glossy magazine for a feature on her work, it should have been an occasion to revel in dressing fabulously. The problem? title: The Key to Easy Home-Baked Danishes
summary: With a little help from frozen puff pastry, it's surprisingly simple to produce these impressive breakfast treats. Here are two delicious variations, sweet and savory. I roll down the windows in the car and cruise with a mug of coffee on my knee-and if I time it right, I arrive at my favorite bakery as the first Danishes are exiting the oven. title: This Retro Shirt Will Make You Look Like Jude Law This Summer
summary: As Dickie Greenleaf in 'The Talented Mr. Ripley,' Jude Law had a Riviera wardrobe as covetable as his charm. Here's how to purloin his look. IN THE 1999 film "The Talented Mr. Ripley," adapted from the Patricia Highsmith novel, the title character (Matt Damon) weasels his way into a triangle with the doomed but oh-so-debonair Marge Sherwood (Gwyneth Paltrow) and Dickie Greenleaf (Jude Law) in the Italian seaside hamlet where the couple had planned to live out la dolce vita. Soon, of course, tragedy strikes, but even in the face of catastrophe Mr. Greenleaf manages to wear one of the all-time great summer shirts. It's a 1950s knitted number with a wide collar that flops just like his swoopy hair, and-in the careless way of the young, taut and privileged-he leaves a few of its mother-of-pearl buttons undone.

title: WSJ. Magazine Contributors: June 2019
summary: Photographer Mikael Jansson documented his own Tuscan home for this issue of the magazine. For his 10th WSJ. cover shoot, photographer Mikael Jansson got personal: He headed to Italy to document the Tuscan home he owns with his wife, Lotta. Writer Joshua Levine accompanied him on the journey, noticing the strong link between Jansson's photographic style and the house's interior design. "Someone used the phrase 'refined simplicity' to describe his aesthetic," Levine says. "I can't do better than that." For Jansson, the experience of capturing the spaces was a mix of the familiar and the new. "It felt a bit different and special to shoot your own house for a magazine," he says, but "the approach was pretty much the same as when I shoot fashion. My assistants flew down, and we shot for two days. We woke up at 5 in the morning, waited for the right light in each room. Like a normal shoot, but fewer people. It was fun!"

title: Letter From the Editor: The Quiet Glamour of a Tuscan Retreat
summary: In her monthly editor's letter, WSJ.'s Kristina O'Neill talks about her trip last year to photographer Mikael Jansson's Italian villa, seen here for the first time in publication. Convincing high-profile individuals to appear on WSJ.'s cover is a challenging part of putting out the magazine, and asking Mikael Jansson to focus his camera lens on his own life and home was an especially delicate undertaking. Jansson, among the fashion world's most celebrated photographers, is a private figure who prefers to let his luminous imagery speak for itself. His quiet discretion is just one of the ways he earns the trust of his portrait subjects. Last summer, I was fortunate enough to attend Mikael's 60th birthday party at the Tuscan retreat he and his wife, Lotta, renovated together, a gorgeous property that reflects their shared passion for decorating houses. I knew our readers would be as dazzled as I was to get an inside look at how their beautiful home came together, as documented by Mikael himself; thankfully, in the end he consented. (And it's fitting that the article includes a collage of images Jansson took on his iPhone when the landscape was more green and lush, as the Journal recently announced a partnership with the subscription service Apple News+.) This is Jansson's 10th cover feature for WSJ. and a testament to his exceptional eye for beauty.

title: Everything on U.S. Soccer Star Alex Morgan's iPhone
summary: The co-captain of the national team, slated to suit up for this summer's FIFA Women's World Cup, whiles away long flying hours with this trick. At what battery percentage do you feel compelled to charge your phone? Whenever it goes red. I purposefully don't have the actual percentage on my homescreen as it would stress me out.

title: Home Depot's Sales Lifted by Larger Customer Transactions
summary: Same-store sales growth was weaker than analysts had expected. Home Depot Inc.'s sales rose in the fiscal first quarter, lifted by a rise in the number of customer transactions and stronger spending per visit.

title: The Rustic Charm of an Idyllic Tuscan Hideaway
summary: Resume Subscription. CALLING MIKAEL and Lotta Jansson's Tuscan retreat a hideaway is something of an understatement. Even with precise GPS coordinates it's easy to drive past the weathered iron gate deep in the shadow of some big trees marking the entrance. Beyond the gate, a winding dirt track runs up a hill to another iron gate, which leads you, after a time, to a handsome farmhouse in brick and the yellowish stone that predominates in this region of Italy. Towering cypresses and ancient olive trees ring a wide front lawn, which looks out over a pleasant valley toward nearby ski slopes, still carpeted with snow in April. To paraphrase the French expression, more Tuscan than this and you die.

summary: Mikael and Lotta Jansson found the ideal Tuscan retreat for gathering friends and family. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Japan's Tantalizing Bank Dividends Mask a World of Trouble
summary: Resume Subscription. Japanese bank stocks hit a new, unwanted record last week: the dividend yield on the Topix banks index rose above 4% for the first time since at least 1973, according to Refinitiv data.

title: India Antitrust Watchdog Sniffs Around E-Commerce Players
summary: In a country where Amazon and Walmart's Flipkart dominate, the agency is surveying online retailers to understand the sector's 'implications for competition'. NEW DELHI-India's antitrust watchdog is assessing the domestic e-commerce sector, a step that could have consequences for Amazon.com Inc. and Walmart Inc.'s Flipkart, which dominate online sales in the country.

title: A Tale of Two Yield Curves
summary: Investors watch two-year Treasury yields while the Fed uses three-month rates in assessing the economy. Investors and Federal Reserve officials watch the gaps between shorter- and longer-term interest rates to gauge the health of the U.S. economy. Right now, the two groups are seeing different things.

title: Mid-Career Professionals Look for a Reboot at Coding Boot Camps
summary: Some middle-aged people seeking a career change are enrolling in New York City schools-with varying degrees of success. Andrew Fechner was unemployed nearly a year when he made a radical move: At age 42, with young twin boys to support, he borrowed $19,000 for tuition and enrolled in a 13-week Manhattan coding boot camp. The former cable-television programming executive hoped to launch a new career as a software engineer.

title: Trump to Press for Trade Deal in Trip to Japan
summary: President will also show he is still aligned with Tokyo on North Korea. TOKYO-President Trump travels to Japan this week to keep up the pressure for a trade deal that has raised hackles among Japanese companies, while showing he is still aligned with Tokyo on North Korea policy.

title: Liquor Companies See the Benefits of Sobriety
summary: Strong demand for alcohol-free drinks is a promising trend for booze companies. It's early days, but alcohol-free liquor seems to be on its way in. Counter-intuitively, big liquor companies should reap the rewards.

title: Space Rockets Spark Property Boom on Florida Coast
summary: Cocoa Beach is in the middle of a resurgence as the private space industry brings back jobs and visitors. Jeff Bezos and Elon Musk are racing to send people into outer space and eventually to the moon and Mars. They are already improving the fortunes of a coastal Florida city that is home to their budding space ambitions.

title: Urban Outfitters to Start Renting Clothes
summary: Retailer launches $88 monthly service, jumping into market led by Rent the Runway. Urban Outfitters Inc. is jumping into clothing rental, trying to tap one of the fastest-growing areas of fashion without discouraging shoppers from visiting its stores.

title: Japan's Central Bank Shows How Not to Buy Stocks
summary: After nine years of ETF purchases, the Bank of Japan doesn't have much to show for it. Japan's central bankers have had more success buying bonds than stocks.

title: U.S. Postal Service Starts Testing Self-Driving Trucks
summary: The 1,000-mile run between Phoenix and Dallas is part of a program aimed at making intercity mail transport less expensive and more efficient. The U.S. Postal Service is testing self-driving trucks on a more than 1,000-mile mail run between Phoenix and Dallas, the post office's first use of the technology for long hauls.

title: Sprint's Deal Is Still a Marathon
summary: Sprint and T-Mobile moved closer to a deal with a positive decision from the FCC on Monday, but the market's strong reaction gives a misleading sense of the improved chances. On Monday, the $26 billion combination of T-Mobile and Sprint cleared one of its two federal hurdles to approval.

title: For China, Getting Rich Is Glorious-Getting Old Isn't
summary: Resume Subscription. Why has China grown so fast? One very important reason is that it timed its economic opening to the world exceptionally well.

title: France Goes on Deal Spree, Thanks to ECB Easy Money
summary: Regulators are eyeing French companies' rapidly increasing debt levels. The European Central Bank's efforts to revive growth have spurred a flurry of investment and deal making. One problem is, a bunch of it is happening outside of Europe.

title: YouTube Camp Is an Actual Thing
summary: Parents concerned about YouTube debate whether to let their children have their own channels; some forbid it, others send them to summer camp. What's up guys, it's Julie here. Welcome back to another column. Wait, why am I suddenly talking like a YouTuber? Because today I'm going to tell you about YouTube summer camps for kids.

title: The German Data Diver Who Exposed China's Muslim Crackdown
summary: Scholar digging online revealed scope of detentions; 'I feel very clearly led by God to do this'. KORNTAL, Germany-Research by a born-again Christian anthropologist working alone from a cramped desk in this German suburb thrust China and the West into one of their biggest clashes over human rights in decades.

title: California Democrats Clash Over Health Care for Illegal Immigrants
summary: Governor wants state to cover only those under 26, while legislators push to provide Medicaid to all. SACRAMENTO, Calif.-California lawmakers are headed for a showdown over how many illegal immigrants should qualify for government-subsidized health care.

title: Trade Disputes Are Weakening Future Growth, OECD Says
summary: Business investment to grow at an average 1.75% this year, down from 3.5% in 2017 and 2018. Conflicts between the U.S. and its major trade partners have weakened business investment around the world, threatening to hamper future as well as current rates of economic growth, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said Tuesday.

title: Formula One Legend and Aviation Entrepreneur Niki Lauda Dies
summary: As much as for any of his three championships, he is remembered for his comeback from a horrific crash in 1976. Niki Lauda, the three-time Formula One world champion from Austria who once returned to the track weeks after a fiery crash that scarred him for life, died on Monday night. He was 70.

title: Facial-Recognition Startup Calls for Regulation Instead of Bans
summary: SenseTime co-founder responds to criticism that the technology gives authorities excessive means to spy on the public, erode civil liberties. TOKYO-The co-founder of SenseTime Group Ltd., a Chinese artificial-intelligence startup under fire for the use of its facial-recognition technology in mass-surveillance systems, said its technology should be regulated rather than banned.

title: U.S.-China Trade Talks Will End in a Deal, Former Negotiator Says
summary: Resume Subscription. TOKYO-A former top U.S. trade negotiator said talks with China for a trade deal had made significant progress despite recent setbacks and an agreement would eventually be reached.

title: Oklahoma, Texas Face Risk of Devastating Tornadoes
summary: Powerful storms could bring flooding, baseball-size hail, hurricane-force winds. Forecasters say a dangerous mix of warm air and fast, shifting winds is expected to spawn severe thunderstorms and violent tornadoes from the Texas panhandle into Oklahoma Monday evening and into Tuesday.

title: U.S. Plans Temporary Exemptions to Huawei Blacklist
summary: Reprieve, which could ease U.S.-China tensions, would ensure operations of existing networks. U.S. officials said Monday they would grant a handful of temporary exceptions to an export blacklist against Huawei Technologies Co., giving some suppliers and customers of China's telecom giant a 90-day reprieve from tough trade penalties.

title: T-Mobile, Sprint Get Merger Backing From FCC Chairman
summary: Ajit Pai backs $26 billion deal after cellphone carriers agree to concessions. WASHINGTON-Federal Communications Commission Chairman Ajit Pai said he would back the more than $26 billion combination of cellphone carriers T-Mobile US Inc. and Sprint Corp. after the companies agreed to a package of concessions.

title: Stocks Dragged Down by Tech Sector
summary: Investors worry move against Huawei could further inflame tensions between the U.S. and China. Shares of technology companies skidded after some U.S. businesses moved to comply with restrictions against Huawei Technologies, setting up major stock indexes for another tough week amid the escalating trade spat.

title: Ascena's Dressbarn to Shut Down
summary: Company to close about 650 stores amid a drop in sales. Ascena Retail Group Inc. plans to wind down its Dressbarn retail operations, resulting in the closure of about 650 stores, the company said Monday.

title: Lawmakers Call on Trump for a New U.S. Policy in Syria
summary: 'Ungoverned space' threatens U.S., allies, say GOP, Democratic lawmakers. Hundreds of lawmakers led by senior members of the House and Senate foreign policy committees have written to President Trump calling for a new U.S. strategy in Syria to counter Russia and Iran, deter terrorists and safeguard Israel.

title: When Beauty Industry Is Inclusive, Everyone Wins
summary: With needs of women of color often underserved by mainstream cosmetics brands, entrepreneurs go for untapped market. Author

title: Fed's Powell Warns of Economic Risks From Rising Business Debt
summary: Some comparisons between rising corporate debt and subprime mortgage crisis, however, are 'not fully convincing'. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said financial regulators must take seriously potential dangers that rising levels of business debt pose to the U.S. economy but said some comparisons to last decade's subprime-mortgage bubble overstate the risks.

title: McConnell Pushes to Raise Age for Tobacco Purchases to 21
summary: Aiming to curb e-cigarette use, Senate GOP leader teams with Democrat Tim Kaine to introduce legislation boosting minimum age from 18 to 21. WASHINGTON-Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) introduced legislation to increase the minimum age for purchasing tobacco products to 21, joining with a Democrat in what he has called one of the Senate's highest priorities.

title: Cohen Says Trump Lawyer Suggested He Give False Testimony About Moscow Project
summary: Cohen falsely testified that negotiations over a Trump Tower in Moscow ended in January 2016, transcript shows. WASHINGTON-Michael Cohen, a former lawyer for President Trump, told the House Intelligence Committee earlier this year that he believed an attorney for the president suggested he falsely tell the committee in 2017 that negotiations for a Trump Tower in Moscow ended in January 2016, according to a transcript of his closed-door testimony the committee released Monday.
